Potential Failure Mode: Intermittent scan when actuating trigger button
Potential Causes: Worn out rubber boot allowing for dust accumulation in the trigger assembly resulting to interruption of electrical connection
Preventive Controls: Design actuation posts that allows for distributed actuation load (maximum surface contact area) as opposed to point load resulting to premature contact point wear out.
Detection Controls: Trigger button actuation life cycle test

Potential Failure Mode: Cracking of the plastic button
Potential Causes: Thermal expansion stress from insert molded metal.
Preventive Controls: Use of soft transition material such as Silicone (dip and cure insert prior to molding)
Detection Controls: Simulation test to assess difference in thermal expansion rates

Potential Failure Mode: Cracking of the plastic button
Potential Causes: Plastic material has low chemical resistance under constant stress
Preventive Controls: Use semi-crystalline materials such as Celcon M90 (POM)
Detection Controls: Chemical resistance test

Potential Failure Mode: Trigger button not working
Potential Causes: Fatigue damage to FPC trigger button sub-assembly due to repeated contact and separation with the button plastic component
Preventive Controls: Trigger stack up tolerance analysis to allow for sufficient clearance from FPC when button is activated
Detection Controls: Trigger actuation life test with applied force towards the higher side of expected range

Potential Failure Mode: Trigger button not working
Potential Causes: Fatigue damage to FPC trigger button sub-assembly due to repeated contact and separation with the button plastic component
Preventive Controls: Trigger stack up tolerance analysis to allow for sufficient clearance from FPC when button is activated
Detection Controls: Teardown inspection following completion of actuation life test

Potential Failure Mode: Beeper function inoperative
Potential Failure Effects: No beep sound to confirm successful scan.
Potential Causes: Single solder pad design does not provide sufficient solder shear strength to sustain stress induced during Mechanical testing e.g. Drops or Tumble test.
Preventive Controls: Adopt web solder pad design instead of single solder pad design
Detection Controls: Teardown inspection to confirm solder condition after Drops and Tumble test

Potential Failure Mode: Water ingress on speaker
Potential Causes: Speaker sealing surface not flat and not smooth
Preventive Controls: Locate tool ejector pin and mold gates way from sealing surface areas
Detection Controls: Dust and water ingress protection test

Potential Failure Mode: Distorted audio
Potential Causes: Improper fitting of acoustic seal due to poor keypad mold and acoustic sealing design.
Preventive Controls: Design mold and pin insert for proper fitting.
Detection Controls: Audio quality tests and Ingress Protection tests

Potential Failure Mode: Distorted audio
Potential Causes: Speaker coil wire fatigue
Preventive Controls: Compliance to part specifications
Detection Controls: Speaker Stress Test

Potential Failure Mode: Distorted audio
Potential Causes: Speaker coil wire fatigue
Preventive Controls: Compliance to part specifications
Detection Controls: Build-as-Designed (BAD) analysis

Potential Failure Mode: Distorted audio
Potential Causes: Insufficient acoustic enclosure design allowed foreign material to accumulate on Speaker
Preventive Controls: Compliance to part specifications
Detection Controls: Dust and water ingress protection test

Potential Failure Mode: Broken USB connector
Potential Causes: Insufficient connector mechanical support
Preventive Controls: Add mechanical anchor re-inforcement on connectors
Detection Controls: Bend test with cable attached to terminal

Potential Failure Mode: Cradle pin cross contact to incorrect Terminal pin
Potential Failure Effects: Electrical damage to Terminal resulting to feature loss
Potential Causes: Key alignment feature insufficient to prevent cross contact when Terminal is docked in random fashion
Preventive Controls:
The complete range of motion must be evaluated when analyzing terminal-to-cradle interface since the end  user will dock the terminal in a random fashion.  Geometry of the terminal-to-cradle interface must be verified to prevent misalignment of the connection under multiple insertion/ placement scenarios. 
CAD models should be manipulated to evaluate worst case docking orientations and angles. Tolerance analyses performed with the system in these configurations.
Detection Controls: Insertion life test with complete range of motions while docking followed by full function check

Potential Failure Mode: Cradle not charging terminal
Potential Failure Effects: Device not working.  Battery not charged.
Potential Causes: Misalignment between cradle pogo pins and Terminal I/O connector contacts.
Preventive Controls: Define critical dimensions on 2D print
Detection Controls: Confirm pin-to-charge contact alignment during insertion test

Potential Failure Mode: Melted plastic housing during charging
Potential Failure Effects: Electrical damage to Terminal resulting to feature loss
Potential Causes: Misalignment between cradle pogo pins and Terminal I/O connector contacts.
Preventive Controls: EE / ME design guidelines
Detection Controls: Terminal insertion life test with device in operating mode

Potential Failure Mode: Intermittent connection between device and power cable
Potential Causes: Critical dimension/alignment and tolerances were not defined for proper connection
Preventive Controls: Tolerance analysis on critical dimensions
Detection Controls: Measure contact pressure on contact pins

Potential Failure Mode: Broken USB cable
Potential Causes: Premature fatigue failure due to insufficient glue coverage used as strain relief
Preventive Controls: Compliance to part specs
Detection Controls: Cable bend cycle test

Potential Failure Mode: Pogo pins wearing out prematurely on vehicle cradle
Potential Failure Effects: Intermittent connection between cradle and terminal
Potential Causes: Terminal is not fully secured to cradle due to lack of sufficient retention feature to prevent movement
Preventive Controls: Position pogo pins in 90 degree offset from the vertical direction to avoid impact from weight of terminal
Detection Controls: Insertion life test in random fashion

Potential Failure Mode: Spare battery gets unseated from charge cradle battery compartment
Potential Causes: Insufficient engagement between retention clip and spare battery
Preventive Controls: Define spare battery retention force in battery compartment
Detection Controls: Measure battery retention force

Potential Failure Mode: Battery contact chatter
Potential Causes: Dimensions incompatibility due to parts tolerance
Preventive Controls: Define critical dimensions on print and perform tolerance analysis
Detection Controls: Design margin testing

Potential Failure Mode: Swelling of battery pack
Potential Causes: Continuous battery discharge due to lack of independent HW comparator
Preventive Controls: Define under voltage threshold within the battery cell capability
Detection Controls: Verify power sequence with device going to suspend when power key is pressed following critical suspend

Potential Failure Mode: Swelling of battery pack
Potential Causes: Continuous battery discharge due to lack of independent HW comparator
Preventive Controls: Verify use of comparator independent of PMIC to disconnect battery from terminal at critical voltage level for software lockup immunity
Detection Controls: Verify power sequence with device going to suspend when power key is pressed following critical suspend

Potential Failure Mode: Solder joint crack on battery contact block pins
Potential Causes: Shear force on contact block during battery insertion to terminal
Preventive Controls: Add mechanical support feature to battery contact block
Detection Controls: Battery insert / remove life test

Potential Failure Mode: Crack on Thermistor FPC
Potential Causes: Battery FPC layout and connector pin design
Preventive Controls: No step on FPC path
Detection Controls: Drops and Tumble Tests

Potential Failure Mode: Crack on Thermistor FPC
Potential Causes: Battery FPC layout and connector pin design
Preventive Controls: No "Z" type bending on FPC
Detection Controls: Drops and Tumble Tests

Potential Failure Mode: Broken battery terminal contacts
Potential Causes: Insufficient mechanical strength to hold large battery mass during drop
Preventive Controls: Add mechanical support feature to prevent battery cell movement
Detection Controls: Drops and Tumble Tests

Potential Failure Mode: Battery not charging
Potential Causes: Battery contacts misalignment due to parts tolerance stack-up
Preventive Controls: Tolerance analysis on critical dimensions
Detection Controls: Battery inserion life test in random fashion

Potential Failure Mode: Pogo pins broken / detached
Potential Causes: Pogo pins and battery housing colliding due to Interference during battery installation.
Preventive Controls: Design should consider the full range of motion of the battery during installation and removal to eliminate possibility of interference with pogo pins
Detection Controls: Battery insert/ remove life test

Potential Failure Mode: Contact pins solder joint fracture
Potential Causes: Interference between battery connector housing and main PCB connector housing causing the solder joints on the battery pins under constant stress.
Preventive Controls: Maintain sufficient clearance between mating connector housings or provision hard stop to prevent interference.
Detection Controls: Drop Test, Tumble Test, AFM, Teardown Inspection

Potential Failure Mode: Glue overflow to connector
Potential Causes: Gap between battery connector pin interface and battery housing which increased over time resulting to moisture ingress.
Preventive Controls: Mating surface seal design guidelines to maintain seal integrity over the expected life of the product
Detection Controls:
Thermal Shock followed by Ingress Protection test; 
Serialized IP test

Potential Failure Mode:
Nickel metal tab connecting battery cell to PCBA fractured during Vibration test breaking electrical
connection
Potential Causes: Nickel tab bend radius forced in a sharp bend due to lack of room for a more gradual bend.
Preventive Controls:
Use of flexible connection approach between battery cell PCBA with sufficient room for a gradual bend radius.
Provide forming fixture during the assembly process to avoid inducing stress nickel tab.
Detection Controls:
Vibration Test
Drop Test 
Tumble Test 
AFM 
X-ray Inspection 
Teardown Inspection

Potential Failure Mode: Internal thermistor lead broke during vibration testing
Potential Causes: No strain relief on Thermistor wire between the thermistor bonding site to the solder connection on the PCBA.
Preventive Controls: Provide strain relief for the Thermistor connection to the PCBA
Detection Controls:
Vibration Test
Drop Test
Tumble Test
X-ray Inspection
Teardown Inspection

Potential Failure Mode: Soldering crack on battery connector after drop test
Potential Causes: No reinforcement feature for the connector to withstand impact shock during drops.
Preventive Controls: Add supporting feature to the connector such as crush ribs.
Detection Controls: Drops and Tumble tests

Potential Failure Mode: Water ingress into the battery connector area during field use. Device is powering off.
Potential Causes: Battery sealing surfaces sustained damage during stand alone drops.
Preventive Controls: Battery sealing surface should be designed to be recessed to prevent direct impact when accidentally dropped.  Add mechanical features such as rubs to protect critical sealing surfaces.
Detection Controls:
Drop simulation study for battery sealing surface.
Serialized IP testing for standalone batteries.

Potential Failure Mode: Water pooling on the terminal's battery connector during field battery swap under heavy rain environment.
Potential Causes: Battery connector is located at the bottom of the TC7X battery well. Water will collect at the terminal connector when the battery is being swapped in the field when under heavy rain.
Preventive Controls:
Battery connector should be strategically located such that water collects in the unsealed portion of the battery
compartment during normal battery removal in it's typical orientation. 
Battery compartment design should have features to promote liquids to flow away from the battery connector. 
Define requirement in PRD to not allow water build up in battery connector area when battery is swapped under rain environment.
Detection Controls:
IPXX test without battery.
IPXX test with battery.
Serialized IP test.

Potential Failure Mode:
Battery Latch requires excessive force to engage.  
TC51 experience.
Potential Failure Effects: Poor customer experience due to difficulty in installing the battery.
Potential Causes:
Insufficient tolerance stack-up analysis.  Geometry of battery and terminal mating surfaces creeped away from nominal dimensions resulting to significant amount of compression force to close the latch.
Critical dimension between mating surface  not specified on drawing.
Preventive Controls:
Define engagement force requirement of battery to Terminal in PRD.
Define critical dimensions on mating parts and conduct tolerance stack-up analysis.
Detection Controls: Worst case simulation of CAD data stack-up on moving part interfaces.

Potential Failure Mode:
Battery cap breaks off during drops. Unable to remove battery from headset and unable to be charged.
Experienced on Viking headset.
Potential Causes: Battery cap is attached to battery pack using glue dispensed on cap and battery pack retention features which is difficult to control and therefore not consistent.
Preventive Controls: Use of mechanical fastener to attached cap to battery pack.
Detection Controls:
Battery install/ remove life test.
Drop test
Tumble test

Potential Failure Mode: Pogo pins height became depressed on WT6000 battery connector
Potential Causes:
During drop sequence on AFM test it was observed that the battery connector pogo pins were depressed.
Investigation showed the pogo pins were pushing out the back of the connector housing.
The pogo housing retention force is not sufficient to maintain pogo pin heights during impact.
Preventive Controls: Design of pogo pin housing should have retention force to maintain pogo pin heights on impact such as support feature under the pogo connector.
Detection Controls:
Drop test.
Tumble test.
AFM test.
Teardown inspection.
Review of supplier test data on pogo pin life tests.

Potential Failure Mode: LAN & GPS antennae broke off during drop test
Potential Failure Effects: Unable to connect to Wi-Fi and GPS
Potential Causes: Poor anchoring.
Preventive Controls:
Design for adequate anchoring such as more than one screw to support antenna assembly or add epoxy for reinforcement.
Pad size optimization for good solder joint. 
Design to account for part interference during drops and tumbles.
Detection Controls:
Drop tests.
Tumble test.

Potential Failure Mode: Poor radio signal strength.
Potential Causes: Inadequate details on part drawing for minimum wire stripping, wire forming and proper routing/ bending.
Preventive Controls:
3D model and tolerance analysis must allow for adequate wire/insulation space within the assembly.
Crimp type antenna connectors have specified pull force.
Design or manufacturing specification identifies minimum wire stripping, wire forming, proper routing/bending to minimize variation.
Shield solder area has adequate solder pad size/dimension for hand soldering.
Insulation present up to solder joint (no unshielded, stripped bare wire suspended beyond solder joint).
Solder flux splatter must not find its way to other PCB areas, assemblies or parts.
Detection Controls:
Vibration, Drops, Tumble tests and measure radio transmit and receive signal strength.
Process control including Go/NG gage for solder strips, visual inspection of wire soldering and SPC for connector pull force.

Potential Failure Mode: LAN & GPS antennae broke off during drop test
Potential Failure Effects: Unable to connect to Wi-Fi or GPS
Potential Causes: Poor anchoring.
Preventive Controls:
Design for adequate anchoring such as more than one screw to support antenna assembly or add epoxy for reinforcement.
Pad size optimization for good solder joint. 
Design to account for part interference during drops and tumbles.
Detection Controls:
Drop tests.
Tumble test.

Potential Failure Mode: Poor radio signal strength.
Potential Causes: Inadequate details on part drawing for minimum wire stripping, wire forming and proper routing/ bending
Preventive Controls:
3D model and tolerance analysis must allow for adequate wire/insulation space within the assembly.
Crimp type antenna connectors have specified pull force.
Design or manufacturing specification identifies minimum wire stripping, wire forming, proper routing/bending to minimize variation.
Shield solder area has adequate solder pad size/dimension for hand soldering.
Insulation present up to solder joint (no unshielded, stripped bare wire suspended beyond solder joint).
Solder flux splatter must not find its way to other PCB areas, assemblies or parts.
Detection Controls:
Vibration, Drops, Tumble tests and measure radio transmit and receive signal strength.
Process control including Go/NG gage for solder strips, visual inspection of wire soldering and SPC for connector pull force.

Potential Failure Mode: Connector broken
Potential Causes:
Insufficient mechanical support.
Poor solder joint.
Preventive Controls:
Design should provision for adequate mechanical anchoring.
Design and component selection should minimize component overhang from PCB to eliminate cantilever effects.
Detection Controls: Bend testing with cable inserted into connector to identify weak points.

Potential Failure Mode: Cradle pin cross contact to incorrect Terminal pin
Potential Causes: Poor alignment between terminal and cradle as cradle pins come into close proximity with terminal connector.
Preventive Controls:
The complete range of motion must be evaluated when analyzing terminal-to-cradle interface since the end  user will dock the terminal in a random fashion.  Geometry of the terminal-to-cradle interface must be verified to prevent misalignment of the connection under multiple insertion/ placement scenarios. 
CAD models should be manipulated to evaluate worst case docking orientations and angles. Tolerance analyses performed with the system in these configurations.
Detection Controls: Insertion life test with complete range of motions while docking followed by full function check.

Potential Failure Mode: Corrosion on USB connector
Potential Causes: Poor use case definition and poor mechanical design anticipating failure during typical use resulting to USB connector corroding due to customer environmental use-case.
Preventive Controls:
Define customer use-case environment.
Design compatible plating, mating geometries, tolerance and alignment/ compression or contact area impedance meets expected connector useful life.
Detection Controls:
IPXX test.
Insertion life test.
Tug/ bend and rotation test.
Chemical resistance test.

Potential Failure Mode: Cracked solder joints on micro USB receptacle
Potential Causes:
Insufficient micro USB receptacle mounting/solder strength to withstand daily usage. 
 
(Micro USB's are being used more than expected on devices and need to make sure design is robust enough to withstand  increase of use).
Preventive Controls:
Provide design features that would prevent relative motion of the receptacle.  If design is limited, add epoxy for reinforcement.
Consider Organic Solder Preservative (OSP) or Electroless Nickel Electroless Palladium Immersion Gold (ENEPIG) plating instead of Electroless Nickel Immersion Gold (ENIG) on PCB.
Detection Controls:
Insertion life test.
Test to point of failure to establish design margin.

Potential Failure Mode: USB adapter disconnects easily from terminal during use
Potential Causes: The micro USB connector has insufficient strength to withstand being pulled out of the inner-mold/ over-mold on lateral forces.
Preventive Controls:
Select robust connector design i.e. with top and bottom covers providing greater resistance against lateral forces.
Tolerance analysis to maintain minimum gap between the connector over-mold and receptacle to limit pivoting.
Detection Controls: Perform off-axis bend testing to establish force required to cause failure and expose failure mode.  Do not limit testing to only the axis of insertion.

Potential Failure Mode: Magnets are falling off from the snap-on USB charge cable.
Potential Causes: Cable design is lacking sufficient retaining feature for the magnet
Preventive Controls: Design retaining features that will constrain the magnet from moving in XYZ directions.
Detection Controls:
Vibration test.
Drop test.
Tumble test.

Potential Failure Mode: Finger print reader detached from holder
Potential Failure Effects: Loss of finger print reader capability
Potential Causes: Lack of designed features to protect sensitive components from direct impacts
Preventive Controls:
Provide protective features such as raised surfaces or ribs designed to prevent sensitive components from direct impacts.
Verify from CAD modelling/ simulation the compression modulus of selected material is capable of protecting sensitive components.
Select PSA material with temperature range compatible with product use-case.
Detection Controls:
Operating temperature cycling test.
Design margin test.
Drop test.
IPXX test.

Potential Failure Mode: Camera window adhesion failure
Potential Causes:
Sealing surface not texturing not compatible for PSA application i.e., not flat and smooth.
PSA rating not compatible with product operating temperature range.
Preventive Controls:
Specify surface requirements for effective PSA attachments i.e. texture, smooth surface. 
Process control for PSA attachment using fixtures for consistent pressure and duration.
Detection Controls:
Vibration test.
Drop test across temperature.
Tumble test.

Potential Failure Mode: Poor sealing surface design
Potential Failure Effects: Loss of function due to water or dust ingress
Potential Causes: Mating surface is not flat and smooth due to surface texturing, ultrasonic welding, ejector marks or parting lines.
Preventive Controls:
Specify requirement for sealing mating surfaces to be flat and smooth.
Tool ejector pin location and molding gates are not on sealing surfaces.
Detection Controls: Thermal shock followed by IPXX test.

Potential Failure Mode: Scan exit window detaching
Potential Causes: Mating surface design not compatible with ultrasonic welding process i.e. size of energy director.
Preventive Controls: Design mating surface and energy director that is compatible with ultrasonic welding process.
Detection Controls:
Verify scan window push out force meet specified requirement.
Drop test.
Tumble test.
IPXX test.

Potential Failure Mode: Paint peeling and bubbling on plastic surface
Potential Causes: Material selection not compatible with customer use-case
Preventive Controls: Select compatible designs with the use-case such as In Mold Decoration (IMD).
Detection Controls: Tests for outdoor use such Solar Radiation, Chemical Resistance test and Abrasion test.

Potential Failure Mode: Gun handle over-mold peeling from the substrate plastic
Potential Causes:
Overmold material on handle is too soft and absorbs hand oils causing it to lose adhesion to the substrate
plastic over time.
Preventive Controls:
Specify over-mold material with higher shore durometer e.g. 90 shore on high touch surfaces.
Add features in the design of the substrate such as ribs or slots to increase surface contact area.
Detection Controls: Perform over-mold adhesion testing as outlined in 00-M911-TP08 test procedure.

Potential Failure Mode: IP6X test failure
Potential Causes:
Flex used for sealing between outside environment contained through holes due to a cost reduction effort (removal of component
but no change to flex)
Preventive Controls: Flexes should not be used to create an IP seal for a device. Use suitable seal design e.g. PSA or rubber seal.
Detection Controls: IPXX test

Potential Failure Mode: Mura appearing on display when touch panel is activated.
Potential Failure Effects: Appearance of localized distortion on display
Potential Causes: Pressure induced to the back of Display when Touch Panel is activated due to lack of clearance between the Display and underlying components causing interference.
Preventive Controls:
Provide sufficient clearance between the back of display and underlying components.    Less rigid display
components will need higher clearance to accommodate tendency to bend when Touch Panel is activated.
Detection Controls: Include display mura symptom in the list of check items during Engineering and Qualification testing.

Potential Failure Mode: Display showing random lines on screen
Potential Causes: Lack of supporting features on display integration allowing for movement during impact resulting to damage on Display FPC.
Preventive Controls: Provide fillers e.g. foam pad to fill up void area between FPC bend area and edge of Display to restrict movement during impact.
Detection Controls: Teardown inspection on test samples following Drop tests

Potential Failure Mode: Light leakage on Display
Potential Causes: Peeling off of LED light bar from Back Light Unit (BLU) frame allowing for light to leak out.
Preventive Controls: Select adhesive material that can effectively perform at extreme temp.
Detection Controls:
High temperature Burn-in
Drop Test
Tumble Test

Potential Failure Mode: Light leakage on display
Potential Causes: Excessive pressure being applied to the backlight in display integration stack-up design.
Preventive Controls:
Minimize compression to the backlight in the display integration
 - LCD rubber boot
 - EMI spring position and force
Detection Controls:
Tolerance Analysis on display stackup to check for possible interference and verify equal compression around entire perimeter.

Manufacturing test under various display color backgrounds.

Potential Failure Mode: Ripples on display
Potential Failure Effects: Appearance of localized distortion on display
Potential Causes: Deformation of the backlight diffuser film due to lack of sufficient anchor points resulting to the locating anchors to deform during mechanical tests
Preventive Controls: Design for sufficient anchor points to support the backlight diffuser film from folding during mechanical tests.
Detection Controls:
Drop Test
Tumble Test

Potential Failure Mode: Display not working
Potential Causes: Crack on FPC display due to abrupt change in thickness causing sharp bend radius and high strain on FPC conductors.
Preventive Controls:
Design guidelines on FPC around bend areas
1) FPC's identified as dynamic shall specify conductor material as 1mil Rolled Annealed Copper (RA-Cu).
2) Transitions in trace direction shall be placed outside of bend areas and away from areas where the width of the FPC changes.
3) FPC thickness transitions shall not occur within the bend region and shall not be in the same location as the FPC width transition.
4)  Hard stiffener e.g. stainless shall not occur parallel to the same location as the FPC trace.
5) There should be no via holes (PTH) present within the bend region of the FPC.
Detection Controls: Drop and Tumble tests

Potential Failure Mode: Intermittent keys
Potential Failure Effects: Keys may or may not work when pressed.
Potential Causes: Keypad metal dome switch cutting into buried trace under the dome.
Preventive Controls: Review of keypad trace layout against dome array.
Detection Controls: Keypad actuation life test and teardown inspection focusing on keys directly above traces.

Potential Failure Mode: Intermittent Keys
Potential Failure Effects: Keys may or may not work when pressed.
Potential Causes: Metal dome switch obstructed by thickness of solder mask on PCB.
Preventive Controls: Review keypad trace layout and clearance against dome array.
Detection Controls:
Keypad actuation life test
Actuation force measurement on multiple keys

Potential Failure Mode: Keypad connector breaking off from PCB
Potential Causes: Lack of mechanical support on connector.
Preventive Controls:
Select connector with through-hole mechanical support.
Add reinforcement such as epoxy for mechanical support.
Detection Controls:
Drop test
Tumble test

Potential Failure Mode: Keypad connector breaking off from PCB
Potential Causes: Poor solder joint due to limited pad size.
Preventive Controls: Optimize PCB solder pad size for proper solder joint formation.
Detection Controls:
Drop test
Tumble test

Potential Failure Mode: Poor tactile feedback on keys.
Potential Causes: Poor keypad mold and acoustic seal design.
Preventive Controls:
Mold design and pin insert must be in perfect alignment.
Design must provide for proper seal components to fit for adjacent keys to operate.
No parting lines on critical surfaces.
Keypad membrane spec should call out for proper trimming requirements.
Detection Controls:
First Article Inspection on samples from every cavity to confirm compliance with design requirements.
Final test in MFG should include audio quality and echo testing.
Teardown inspection after Drops, Tumble, AFM to confirm no movement in placement of seal components.
Check for tactile feel of all adjacent keys to mic hole.

Potential Failure Mode: Key does not work when activated.
Potential Failure Effects: Unable to operate specific keys on keypad
Potential Causes:
Keypad dome single dimple contact design.
Single dimple design can be susceptible to small particle interference such as skin particles.
Preventive Controls:
Select keypad dome with multiple dimple design.
Specify key actuation force and travel distance.
Detection Controls:
Verify dome design and height/spacing contact point during Engineering test.
Confirm actuation and contact points with pressure sensitive paper.
Measure key actuation force and travel distance.

Potential Failure Mode: Keys or button getting stuck
Potential Failure Effects: Unable to operate key or button.
Potential Causes: Poor mold design.  Parting line interferes with key or trigger button.
Preventive Controls:
Location of mold parting line should be carefully chosen not to interfere with key or trigger button movement.
Design tool such that parting line for key or trigger button recesses occur at the bottom of recess and not at the top or middle section.
Specify maximum allowable parting line in the drawing.
Detection Controls:
Key actuation life test.
Verify tool design for parting line location for key or trigger button recesses.

Potential Failure Mode: Broken solder joints
Potential Failure Effects: Unable to operate switch resulting to function loss.
Potential Causes: Lack of mechanical support to withstand lateral forces
Preventive Controls:
Select switch designs with mechanical PCB through hole support or add supporting mechanical features.
Specified minimum actuation life to be no lower than 1M cycle.
Detection Controls:
Switch or Button actuation life test.
Perform actuation life test with applied force 1.5x the specified actuation force.

Potential Failure Mode: Power button takes excessive force to depress
Potential Failure Effects: Terminal does not power on or off or is very difficult to power on or off
Potential Causes:
Power button flex dome shifted such that no electric contact is made between the dome center and the plated gold area on the flex.
Flex is floating design but no sufficient surface area for Mylar adhesive to bond to the substrate.
Tolerance stack up.
Preventive Controls:
Fixed mount dome designs should be chosen over floating dome designs when possible.
The dome-retaining Mylar must have enough surface around the dome to avoid Mylar to lift over time- refer to the dome switch design guidelines for surface area.
Avoid any steps under the Mylar and dome layer which can result in lift.
Any external plunger for power button activation must be fully aligned with center of terminal power button and switch.
Detection Controls: Switch actuation life test.

Potential Failure Mode: Side trigger actuator post wearing through rubber
Potential Causes: Button post design allow for premature wear out of rubber pill resulting to puncture over time.
Preventive Controls:
Button post should be designed for a distributed actuation force load instead of point load.
Actuation life to be specified according to customer use case.
Detection Controls:
Button actuation life test.
Teardown inspection.

Potential Failure Mode: Premature button failure in freezer environment
Potential Failure Effects: Unable to activate button resulting to function loss.
Potential Causes:
Button does not withstand 1 million actuations at cold because the button gold plating wears away.
Gold plating wears away because debris is allowed to enter between the button plunger and the gold plating.
Debris enters because the enter key membrane tears.
The enter key membrane tears due to the abrasive action of frozen environmental moisture.
Preventive Controls:
Actuation life specification must match customer use-case.
Material selection e.g. silicon membrane temperature rating must match the target operating temperature.
Detection Controls:
Actuation life test.
Teardown inspection.

Potential Failure Mode: Poor acoustics performance
Potential Causes: Acoustic seal interference with adjacent key.
Preventive Controls:
Mold design and pin insert must be in perfect alignment.
Design must provide for proper seal components to fit for adjacent keys to operate.
No parting lines on critical surfaces.
Keypad membrane spec should call out for proper trimming requirements.
Detection Controls:
First Article Inspection on samples from every cavity to confirm compliance with design requirements.
Final test in MFG should include audio quality and echo testing.
Teardown inspection after Drops, Tumble, AFM to confirm no movement in placement of seal components.
Check for tactile feel of all adjacent keys to mic hole.

Potential Failure Mode: Speaker not working
Potential Causes: Coil wire fatigue
Preventive Controls:
Design to meet requirements of MAX drive level receiver test 00-MA71-TPR01.
Design to meet requirements of MAX drive level speaker test 00-MA71-TPS01.
Design to meet requirements of Speaker Stress test.
Detection Controls: Submit samples for Build-As-Designed analysis 00-MA71-BAD01.

Potential Failure Mode: Receiver not working
Potential Causes: Coil wire fatigue
Preventive Controls:
Design to meet requirements of MAX drive level receiver test 00-MA71-TPR01.
Design to meet requirements of MAX drive level speaker test 00-MA71-TPS01.
Design to meet requirements of Speaker Stress test.
Detection Controls: Submit samples for Build-As-Designed analysis 00-MA71-BAD01.

Potential Failure Mode: Variation in Receiver volume and audio quality
Potential Failure Effects: Low volume level and low tone
Potential Causes: The pressure outside and inside of the device is not able to equalize affecting the audio performance when SD card door is inserted to Terminal.
Preventive Controls:
Provision of an actual vent hole in the design of products with with voice communication feature while maintaining IP Seal requirements.
Acoustic chamber must be immune from effects of pressurize enclosure such as SD covers, Seal covers, Battery, Labels, etc.
Enclosure pressure must be equalized if audio components are used and device supports voice applications.
Detection Controls:
Perform acoustic test measurements in production on complete units with all seals in place, SD card door, battery, Labels, etc.
Verify torque setting on screw assembly for audio components.

Potential Failure Mode: ECL test failure
Potential Failure Effects: Poor audio quality and IP seal compromised
Potential Causes: Assembly stack-up and required compression to provide IP seal causing wrinkles on the membrane.
Preventive Controls:
Design should incorporate stack-up and compression to provide sealing and not compromise membrane flatness.
Membrane material selection should consider sealing requirements and assembly stack design intent.
Acoustic chamber boot design should be repeatable and reproducible for assembly in MFG.
Detection Controls: Engineering test on acoustic test limits

Potential Failure Mode: Broken Power Connector
Potential Causes: Insufficient connector mechanical support
Preventive Controls: Add mechanical anchor re-inforcement on connectors
Detection Controls: Bend test with cable attached to terminal

Potential Failure Mode: Not charging through USB port
Potential Causes:
USB connector solder joint cracked on impact during drop test.  Small material thickness of IO dongle could be susceptible to cracking on impact shock.  
Alignment features not sufficient to prevent movement of PCB and material thickness not adequate to prevent damage on impact.
Preventive Controls:
Mechanical design around the USB connector should have adequate alignment features to prevent movement and avoid collision with housing or other mechanical parts.

The material thickness at the critical drop points should be as thick as possible and the radius as large as possible.  Recommended thickness of housing is over 0.8mm and radius larger than 0.5mm.

Add requirements for Melt Flow Index (MFI) on 2D drawing.
Detection Controls:
Drop Test
Tumble test
MFI test at supplier
Break force test at supplier

Potential Failure Mode: Solder fracture and/or Pad Cratering at blade connector to PCB solder joint
Potential Causes:
Design allowed too much movement between the battery and device.
The connector blades move with the battery separate from the rest of the device.
Stress is transferred to the solder joints connecting to the board.
Solder joint may not be sufficiently strong to withstand level of stress and should not be used as the only mechanical strengthening element.
Preventive Controls:
Movement of battery relative to device during stress should be eliminated to minimized.
Strengthen the means of fixing the connector to the board to withstand additional stresses e.g. clips, retaining structure, pin-through-hole, etc.
Identify Critical-to-Quality (CTQ) parts or assembly aspects of the design.
Detection Controls:
Drop test
Tumble test
mini-AFM (test above spec)
Ensure CPK of greater than 1.6 for critical dimensions on battery and related battery compartment features.

Potential Failure Mode: LCD connector cracking at the sides
Potential Causes: Material is brittle.  The high glass fiber content to wall thickness ratio around the walls and sharp corners could make the connector susceptible to cracking based on flex constraints caused by LCD frame.
Preventive Controls:
Material selection.  Choose connector with less brittle material.
Verify material temperature limits.
Design around connector to off-load stresses by ensuring that flex radii is adequate to minimize lateral movement during drops.
Detection Controls:
Drop test
Tumble test
Design margin test (above spec testing)

Potential Failure Mode: Galvanic Corrosion, Anodic, Cathodic Corrosion
Potential Failure Effects: Device goes to suspend when pressed in specific location
Potential Causes: Use of dis-similar metals in the design of mating parts.
Preventive Controls:
Select similar connector and mating flex plated surfaces (refer to MIL-STD-889 guidelines).  Tin flex use only Tin plated mating connector contact leads.  Gold flex use only gold pated mating connector leads. Gold is the preferred plating surface.
Maintain design guidelines to ensure basis for avoiding galvanic corrosion.
Do not allow one supplier control the flex and a different supplier control the connector.
Maintain BOM compliance to ensure multiple sourcing error does not occur.
Detection Controls:
Thermal Shock
High Temperature and Humidity test
Teardown inspection following test exposure focusing on mating surfaces
First Article Inspection to confirm compliance to plating requirements

Potential Failure Mode: Corrosion on Contact between Keypad Flex Gold Contact and Pogo Pin Connector
Potential Failure Effects: Intermittent connection resulting to intermittent operation of keypad
Potential Causes:
Insufficient plating thickness.
Base copper type.
Preventive Controls:
Design contacts on Flex with hard gold plating at 40 +/- 10 micro inches, Electrolytic plated finish, Gold over Nickel.

Design layout that will support Electrolytic plating.

Design pogo pin contacts with hard and thick gold plating at 40 +/- 10 micro inches, Gold over Nickel, Nickel at 180 +/- 60 micro inches

Use thin adhesive with sufficient backing stiffener to prevent Flex contact force from denting when pogo pins apply force on pads.
Detection Controls:
Life cycle test.
Teardown inspection.

Potential Failure Mode: Sub miniature version A (SMA) connector premature failure after 20 mating/un-mating cycles
Potential Failure Effects: Unable to transmit or receive RF signals.
Potential Causes: Requirement for the external antenna connector mating cycles not explicitly defined in part specs.
Preventive Controls: Life cycle requirement for Mating and Un-mating cycles of external antenna connectors must be explicitly defined in part drawing.
Detection Controls: Antenna mating and un-mating life cycle test.

Potential Failure Mode: 54% Battery Charge Level Error
Potential Failure Effects: Battery not charging. LED's indicate battery not charging and may require battery removal and re-insertion to recover.
Potential Causes:
Fretting corrosion on battery connector resulting from,
- vibration induced wear on both contact surfaces
- high relative movement of battery within the terminal resulting in excessive abrasion
- base material is exposed then oxidation takes place causing increased contact resistance
Preventive Controls:
Plating specifications should be in compliance to Zebra Plating Standards and Guidelines.
Perform simulation studies to evaluate relative motion/ possible wear between contact surfaces.
Reduce free movement of battery relative to the Terminal.
Detection Controls:
Vibration Test
Oak Box Test
Teardown inspection of contact surfaces

Potential Failure Mode: Scan engine not working
Potential Causes:
Connector lock-bar position is too close to back housing resulting to collision during impact shock causing the lock-bar to unlock.
Use of Kapton tape as reinforcement for the lock-bar which is not reliable due to effects of temperature on tape adhesion.
Preventive Controls: Increase distance between components that could collide during impact shock or add features such as radiuses to allow for maximum gap.
Detection Controls:
Drop Test
Tumble Test
Teardown Inspection

Potential Failure Mode: Free hanging ferrite causes flex to disconnect
Potential Causes: Ethernet flex connecting the main board and 4-slot board either becomes disconnected or damaged due to relative movement between the ferrite and the PCB which is caused by the ferrite not being secured.
Preventive Controls: Design should not allow for any unsupported mass or suspended from an electrical flex.
Detection Controls:
Drop Test
Vibration Test

Potential Failure Mode: Cracks on FPC traces
Potential Failure Effects: Scan engine not working, unable to read barcode
Potential Causes: Excessive stress on FPC traces during 180 degree bend installation.
Preventive Controls:
Design should avoid excessive bend angle during installation.
Recommended FPC trace width should be over 0.1mm.
Detection Controls:
Drop Test
Tumble Test
X-ray inspection of FPC traces checking for micro cracks

Potential Failure Mode: Vertical locking flex connector opens up during mechanical stresses
Potential Failure Effects: Scan engine not working, unable to read barcode
Potential Causes:
Vertical locking connector is unable to withstand mechanical stresses e.g. Drops, Tumbles moving to unlock position.
Application of tape including double tape as reinforcement is insufficient to prevent connector from being unlocked.
Preventive Controls: Select connector with spring loaded latch i.e. automatically springs back to the lock position e.g. Kyocera 6810 series with "one-Touch Locking" feature.
Detection Controls:
Drop Test
Tumble Test
Teardown Inspection
X-ray Inspection of Flex connector position

Potential Failure Mode: Camera stack height shortened after Thermal Shock
Potential Causes: Incorrect foam pad material selection
Preventive Controls:
Ensure material properties of foam pad can sustain effects of Thermal Shock and terminal operating temperature range. 
Tolerance analysis should consider percentage of material shrinkage, percentage of compression, PCB/connector location/height against the exit window.
Detection Controls:
Thermal Shock
Operating Temperature Cycling

Potential Failure Mode: Camera flex connector disconnected during Drop test
Potential Causes: Camera assembly design induced pull force on connector during drops.
Preventive Controls:
Design should ensure Flex material, thickness, shielding does not tug on Camera stack.
Foam/material with Flex design should be able to maintain compression over temperature.
Confirm bend or forming of flex before and after assembly.
Tolerance analysis should include PCB/connector location/height vs exit window and no interference/pressure on flex during Drops or Tumble.
Detection Controls:
Drop Test
Tumble Test
Teardown Inspection
X-Ray inspection

Potential Failure Mode: Crosstalk between LED and Receiver
Potential Causes: Material used for Rubber Boot and Baffle caused a lift in the Touch Panel resulting to light leakage to the sensor.
Preventive Controls:
Design should ensure adequate isolation between LED and Receiver.
Material selected for Rubber Boot should be able to provide adequate compression and not excess outward force.
Conduct simulation study for crosstalk.
Detection Controls:
Thermal Shock
Altitude Test to verify effect of change in pressure
Cpk analysis on P-sensor activation distance

Potential Failure Mode: WLAN antenna breaking off during Drops
Potential Causes: Insufficient anchoring of WLAN antenna
Preventive Controls:
Design should provide for adequate anchoring such as more than 1 holding screw and optimized solder pad size for to facilitate good solder joint.
Design should account for possible interference during impact shock.
Detection Controls:
Drop Test
Tumble Test
Teardown Inspection

Potential Failure Mode: GPS Antenna breaking off during Drops
Potential Causes: Insufficient anchoring of WLAN antenna
Preventive Controls:
Design should provide for adequate anchoring such as more than 1 holding screw and optimized solder pad size for to facilitate good solder joint.
Design should account for possible interference during impact shock.
Detection Controls:
Drop Test
Tumble Test
Teardown Inspection

Potential Failure Mode: Ultrasonic welding mating surface failure causing top cover to detach
Potential Failure Effects: Loss of function due to damage internal components when exposed
Potential Causes: Plastic housing design and assembly design did not provide for adequate room to accommodate wiring assembly resulting to constant force load against ultrasonic welding surfaces.
Preventive Controls:
Perform tolerance analysis on the assembly stack-up to ensure no interference between assembly component that could result to a constant pressure against ultrasonic welding surfaces.

Include use of pressure sensitive paper during ultrasonic welding job setup to verify parallelism between horn, fixture and component ensuring even amount of pressure along the mating surface.
Detection Controls:
Drop Test
Tumble Test
Teardown inspection of ultrasonic welding mating surfaces

Potential Failure Mode: Screw fastener head breaking off during mechanical stress
Potential Failure Effects: Screw loosening compromising structural integrity of product
Potential Causes:
Material selection of screw fastener requiring Zn plating process are susceptible to Hydrogen Embrittlement (HE) of screws which typically occurs as a result of the required acid bath for Zn electroplating. 
"Rock Candy" morphology with characteristic "crow's feet" indicate inter-granular failure caused by HE.
Preventive Controls:
Design should consider use of Stainless Steel screws instead of Zn plated (or any other plating e.g. Ni) to eliminate the need for acid bath required in electroplating process.
Consult galvanic series table to assess material compatibility.
Detection Controls:
Drop Test
Tumble Test 
Teardown inspection checking for fractures on screws and other mechanical components.
In case of electro-plated screws, audit of supplier to verify post-plate baking is a controlled process (specifically time between plating and bake, temp., time of bake) and QC testing using ASTM F519

Potential Failure Mode: Touch Panel Assembly popping out during Drop test
Potential Causes:
Contamination from VHB tape release liner reduced tape adhesion by 50%.
Double-sided Tape (DST) part drawing did not specify adhesive performance requirement for Peel Strength.
Preventive Controls:
Specify DST adhesion requirement on part drawing.
Define process control for VHB application i.e., assembly fixture, pressure and duration.
Compliance to Process Change Notification (PCN) requirements.
Detection Controls:
Perform peel strength measurement post Thermal Shock following ASTM3330.
Drop test across temperature
Tumble Test

Potential Failure Mode: Speaker Grill detaching during cold drops
Potential Causes:
Mating surfaces are smooth which does not make good contact surface for adhesive.
Tolerance analysis indicating assembly stack-up e.g. housing flatness, grill flatness and press head flatness is larger than the adhesive thickness.
Flatness requirement not defined on plastic housing and grill.
Preventive Controls:
Design should avoid using adhesive on cosmetic area and bonding between different components solely relying on adhesive.  Design should incorporate specific features to ensure a stronger bond.

In cases where adhesives cannot be avoided,
Design should add mechanical features as reinforcement.
Design should define the flatness of related components and run tolerance analysis to ensure the adhesive can be fully bonded.

Process Controls for adhesive bonding,
Flatness of the press fixture should be considered.
Conduct pressure sensitive paper test at job setup to ensure fixture press head is operating properly.
Regular check on press head fixture for signs of wear out.
Clean mating surfaces either by plasma or IPA.
Detection Controls:
Drop Test across temperature
Tumble Test
Teardown inspection on mating surfaces bonded with adhesive

Potential Failure Mode: Hand Strap stitching coming loose
Potential Causes: Stitching is minimal and is constantly abraded when terminal is placed flat on back.
Preventive Controls:
Hand strap stitching should be designed with double box stitching pattern.
Avoid placing hand strap stitching on area that will constantly be in contact with abrasive surfaces.
Detection Controls: Conduct cardboard abrasion test.

Potential Failure Mode: Hand Strap binds when terminal is inserted into charge cradle
Potential Causes: Physical interference between the hand strap and the charge cradle.
Preventive Controls:
All accessories must be checked for cross compatibility.  
The checking process would be facilitated if there is an existing comprehensive list of accessories and its corresponding design maturity.
Detection Controls: Insertion testing on all cradles while integral accessories e.g. hand strap, tether, stylus are installed on the terminal.

Potential Failure Mode: Housings are cracking in Healthcare environment
Potential Causes: Over-molding can result in tensile strains which make the material more susceptible to chemical attack.
Preventive Controls: Avoid designs requiring over-molding and two shot molding processes for Healthcare products.
Detection Controls:
Thermal Shock
Chemical Resistance Test
Drop Test
Tumble Test
Process Sign Off (PSO) by supply chain SDE check ensure the plastic molded parts are being made correctly, material dried correctly,
process controls in place at supplier.

Potential Failure Mode: Housings are cracking in Healthcare environment
Potential Causes: Placement of fastening screws typically in the corners result to housing distortion during assembly causing significant tensile strain.
Preventive Controls:
Designs should space the assembly screws such that the unit uniformly compresses the seal without distorting the
housing.
Detection Controls:
Thermal Shock
Chemical Resistance test
Drop Test
Tumble Test

Potential Failure Mode: Housings are cracking in Healthcare environment
Potential Causes: Use of Lexan 9330 which does not have good chemical resistance.  Cleaning agents used in the medical industry such as Vionexous and Virex are known to degrade the strength of plastics.
Preventive Controls: Select plastic material that are resistant to cleaning agents used in health case environment.
Detection Controls:
Thermal Shock
Chemical Resistance Test

Potential Failure Mode: Rubber bumpers coming off Aluminum housing
Potential Failure Effects: Decrease/ loss of rubber bumpers protection
Potential Causes:
Aggressive disinfectant chemical cleaners compromised the  acrylic based PSA used to adhere bumper to aluminum
housing.
Preventive Controls: Do not use acrylic based adhesives for applications which require disinfectant cleaning. These applications require silicone based adhesives which can withstand rigorous cleaning found in Health Care environments.
Detection Controls:
Thermal Shock
Chemical Resistance Test

Potential Failure Mode: Resilience HC8230 warps at typical storage temperature & exposure to UV radiation
Potential Causes: Resilience HC8230 deflection temperature under load is 69.4C which is relatively low.  Internal stresses relax and result in warpage. Zebra Internal testing (High Temp. Storage & UV Sunlight Exposure) revealed dimensional changes after exposure rendering the samples not usable.
Preventive Controls: Consider using Polyvinyl chloride alloy alternatives. Geon HTX M6215 extends heat distortion temperature above standard PVC (77.8C vs 69.4C) and has excellent low temperature impact performance.
Detection Controls:
Thermal Shock
Chemical Resistance Test
Storage Temperature Test
Solar Radiation Test

Potential Failure Mode: Corrosion on electrical contacts when exposed to bleach based disinfectants
Potential Failure Effects: Function loss due to degradation in conductivity of electrical contacts
Potential Causes: Corrosive nature of bleach based disinfectants.
Preventive Controls:
Apply gold plating post stamping/ bending process to guarantee sufficient and consistent plating thickness and prevent any base material exposure which could result to corrosion.
Use disinfectant resistant epoxy coating/painting on exposed metal surfaces. Do not use any acrylic based paint or coatings.
Detection Controls:
Thermal Shock
Chemical Resistance test

Potential Failure Mode: Plastic boss on battery pack housing holding the magnet is cracking
Potential Failure Effects: Plastic boss cannot hold magnet resulting to battery unable to be secured to terminal.
Potential Causes: Magnet geometry interferes with the plastic boss dimension resulting to high stress concentration and makes the material more susceptible to effects of chemical attack.
Preventive Controls:
Avoid interference in design. Conduct tolerance analysis of areas designed to be in a state of constant stress which can result in plastic cracking.
Minimize reveals and features in the design which can trap environmental substances that can adversely affect plastic components over time.
Detection Controls:
Thermal Shock
Enhanced chemical resistance test on battery standalone units including wipe test.

Potential Failure Mode: Inaudible user calls
Potential Failure Effects: Unable to communicate with other users
Potential Causes: Medical use requires frequent disinfection of devices with antiseptics that attack plastics and adhesives. Dust and debris, makeup particles and skin flakes get washed into a slurry that is then forced into the grill holes resulting to degradation of audio performance.
Preventive Controls:
Designs for medical applications must use materials resistant to chemical attack such as PPSU plastics rather than PET or Polycarbonate. 
The design of audio holes should consider minimizing of clogging and add features to facilitate cleaning.
Detection Controls:
Thermal Shock
Chemical Resistance Test 
Dust Ingress Test
Clogging test developed from SPR 34296

Potential Failure Mode: PPSU power key falling off
Potential Failure Effects: Difficult to activate power button.  Poor tactile feel.
Potential Causes: Loctite 5055 used to bond the power button cap is not compatible with PPSU material which has high chemical resistance property required in healthcare industry.
Preventive Controls:
Design should consider use of mechanical retention feature to hold the power button cap instead of adhesive bonding specially with PPSU material. 

Alternative option is Liquid Injection Mold (LIM) process to bond PPSU and rubber.
Detection Controls:
Thermal Shock
Chemical Resistance Test
Pull out force test

Potential Failure Mode: Main housing cosmetic defect on secondary surface
Potential Causes: Texturing of VDI-18 on PPSU plastic surface is too light making the surface susceptible to effects of sulfidation of the barrel of the injection molding machine.
Preventive Controls: Surface texturing should not be lighter than VDI-30 for PPSU plastic material.
Detection Controls:
First Article Inspection.
Process Sign Off (PSO) at supplier injection molding process for tooling cleaning frequency.

Potential Failure Mode: Stylus tether breaks easily when pulled
Potential Failure Effects: Unable to secure stylus to the terminal
Potential Causes: Tether has insufficient tensile strength. The method of manufacturing the tether crimp result to weakening of the cord material.  Design of tether using in-elastic loop with elastic mid-region required over-molding process causing the tensile strength to be significantly reduced.
Preventive Controls:
Pull force spec must be defined in the PRD.  Pull force should be near the maximum pull strength as outlined in safety breakaway guidelines.
Avoid use of elastic tethers that have inherently lower tensile strength compared to in-elastic tethers.
Avoid using metal crimp where it could be in close proximity of charge I/O contacts.
Detection Controls: First Article Inspection to confirm conformance to pull force requirements.

Potential Failure Mode: Soft holster belt clip leather tears at attachment point to holster
Potential Failure Effects: Holster can rotate freely as opposed to being stationary.
Potential Causes: Tearing of the belt clip attachment to holster.  A rotating belt clip design is used for non-rotating application with stitching applied to restrict rotation.
Preventive Controls:
Specify the correct component for the target application e.g. non-moving components for stationary applications.
Part drawing to specify the materials and components to be used in the assembly to prevent suppliers from using alternatives without proper notification to Zebra.
Detection Controls:
First article inspection.
Life cycle testing.

Potential Failure Mode: Nylon finger strap premature wear out
Potential Failure Effects: Unable to secure ring scanner to fingers
Potential Causes:
Lack of finger strap material durability required for the target use-case.
Double loop buckle design for the finger strap resulting to abrasion damage.
Single stitching on the finger strap velcro not adequate for the target use-case.
Preventive Controls:
Use of stronger material for rugged use-case e.g. Hypalon or better.
Use of CAM buckle design instead of belt buckle to minimize abrasion damage to strap.
Specify double stitching or better on finger strap velcro.
Define life cycle requirement in PRD.
Detection Controls: Life cycle testing of finger strap to validate all the components in the finger strap system i.e., Strap material, Buckle, Velcro and Stitching.  Ensure test method is simulating the actual use-case e.g. full insertion, tightening, loosening and removal.

Potential Failure Mode: Rubber finger strap premature wear out
Potential Failure Effects: Unable to secure ring scanners to fingers
Potential Causes: Bumps on Silicon rubber finger strap design creates stress concentration resulting to weakening of the material leading to cracking and eventual breaking.
Preventive Controls:
Use of stronger material for rugged use-case e.g. Hypalon or better.
Use of CAM buckle design instead of belt buckle to minimize abrasion damage to strap.
Specify double stitching or better on finger strap velcro.
Define life cycle requirement in PRD.
Detection Controls:
Life cycle testing of finger strap to validate all the components in the finger strap system i.e., Strap material, Buckle, Velcro and Stitching.
Ensure test method is simulating the actual use-case e.g. full insertion, tightening, loosening and removal.

Potential Failure Mode: Soft good holster housing zipper splitting apart
Potential Failure Effects: Unable to secure terminal to holster
Potential Causes: Zipper separates because retention force of zipper pair is not strong enough to withstand force imparted by terminal specially when inserted upside down.  There is no design feature preventing the terminal from being inserted in reverse.
Preventive Controls:
Choose the correct zipper size to match the required retention force.  Larger zipper size provides larger retention force. Require zipper # 5 if used on holster housing.
Provide design features to allow terminal to be inserted only in the correct orientation.
Detection Controls: Insertion life test allowing for insertions to be performed asymmetrically from all possible orientations.

Potential Failure Mode: Labels placed on cable assembly are damaged due to wear location
Potential Failure Effects: Service is unable to recognize serial number and may not honor warranty.
Potential Causes: Label falling off due to mounting location is at a high wear and contact area of the cable. No provision to place regulatory label on the device or in a low contact point area.
Preventive Controls:
Design intentional recess area for labels that is low or minimal exposure during normal use.
Burn-in or print label contents on the part itself.
Apply protective overlay on label to avoid wearing out of label content.
Consider features such as wear beads to minimize label exposures.
Detection Controls: Perform RCA abrasion test on label surface.

Potential Failure Mode: Anti-reflective (AR) coating peeling off exit window
Potential Causes: Poor anti reflective (AR) coating adhesion.  Breakdown of AR coating adhesion due to effects of high temperature and pressure during over-molding process resulting to premature wear-off in the field.
Preventive Controls:
Scan window attachment design should avoid subjecting the window to over-molding process.
Define AR coating adhesion requirement in part drawing.
If possible, design application of AR coating on the inner side of the window to avoid physical contact.
Detection Controls: First article inspection to verify conformance to AR coating adhesion requirements.

Potential Failure Mode: Scan exit window falling off
Potential Failure Effects: Damage due to exposed internal components.  Water and dust ingress.
Potential Causes: Exit window mating surface design not optimized for ultrasonic welding.
Preventive Controls:
Complete texturing coverage of ultrasonic welding mating surface.
Design for adequate energy director size for ultrasonic welding process. 
Ensure horn surface is parallel to the surface being welded during ultrasonic welding.
Detection Controls:
Thermal Shock
Drop Test 
Tumble Test
Exit window push out force test
Chemical test

Potential Failure Mode: Rubber baffle position shifted after drops
Potential Failure Effects: Misaligned or deformed appearance when looking into the scan engine from the scan window.
Potential Causes:
Design of rubber baffle allowed for positional shift due to lack of sufficient rigidity to resist local deflection.
Flaps designed as anchors made on a single plane resulting to insufficient holding strength.
Mating surface has irregular fits instead of flat-to-flat mating causing rubber to get caught and not able to bounce back.
Preventive Controls:
Baffle flange must be design with sufficient rigidity preferably over-molded to plastic to resist defection on impact.
Mating surface must be flat-to-flat as opposed to irregular fits.
The anchor points should be on multi-plane instead of single plane and in continuous flow instead of standalone to enhance holding strength.
Compare simulation results on amount of deflection from reference design.
Detection Controls:
Drop test across temperature on each scan engine configuration
Tumble test on each scan engine configuration
Check for baffle position after test exposure
First Article Inspection checking for flashes that may prevent the baffle from laying flat

Potential Failure Mode: Housings are cracking in Healthcare environment
Potential Causes: Aggressive disinfectant chemical cleaners degrade Poly-carbonate plastics.
Preventive Controls: Products in healthcare industry require consideration for resistance to aggressive disinfectants. Use Poly-vinylchloride (rPVC) or Poly-phenylsulhone (PPSU) or other plastic resins developed for cleaning and disinfecting applications.
Detection Controls:
Thermal Shock
Chemical Resistance test

Potential Failure Mode: Internal wires of cable are breaking
Potential Failure Effects: Charge cable unable to charge terminals
Potential Causes: Strain relief design allows for sharp bending at the transition region from the over-mold to bulk cable causing high stress concentration to the internal wires.
Preventive Controls:
Use a cross-cut pattern in the strain relief design to allow for relaxed bending at all directions.
Progressive reduce the slot opening size towards the connector end to minimize degree of bending close to the connector.
If necessary, use Kevlar strains within the bulk cable to wrap the internal wires to increase resistance from breaking.
Detection Controls:
Thermal Shock
Strain Relief bend test and other applicable test items specified in doc # 70-70984-01.

Potential Failure Mode: PCB of audio cable breaking when audio connector is plugged-in
Potential Causes: Lack of structural mechanical support to prevent the cable housing assembly from bending when audio connector is plugged-in.
Preventive Controls: Design adequate structural mechanical support to cable housing assembly to enhance rigidity.
Detection Controls: Audio cable insertion life test

Potential Failure Mode: Over-voltage protection circuit failure in host device
Potential Causes: Missing electrical surge protection test from part specifications.
Preventive Controls:
Verify purchasing flow down of Charger adapter specification i.e., 86-70979-02.
Verify supplier test capability is meeting specifications including SAE1145 and ISO7637-02.
If contracting to external lab, ensure accreditation to ISO17025.
Verify supplier NRE includes Surge/Electrical compliance test cost per specifications.
Verify product specifications is based on power supply template document # 00-T612-QTP-01 rev. E or later.
Detection Controls:
Operating temperature cycle test
Design margin tests
Surge/ Immunity tests
Process Sign Off (PSO)
Burn-in test

Potential Failure Mode: Vehicle cradle ball and socket joint nut breaks during normal use
Potential Failure Effects: Vehicle cradle unable to stay in place when mounted.
Potential Causes: Mismatch of off-the-shelf tightening nut thread pitch and vehicle cradle thread design.
Preventive Controls: Verify design compatibility between off-the-shelf components against Zebra design for interference when components are in proper position and orientation.
Detection Controls: Perform fit/ compatibility checks when incorporating off-the-shelf components.

Potential Failure Mode: Headset cable internal wires broken
Potential Failure Effects: Intermittent or noisy audio over headset
Potential Causes: Cable connector design results to repetitive excessive cable bend up to 180 degrees when in normal use.
Preventive Controls:
Cable connectors should be designed to operate in neutral position instead of being subjected to excessive and perpetual bend.
Product reference guides should prohibit users from placing devices in pockets where cables could be bent excessively or used as handles to move wearable devices around.
Detection Controls:
Thermal Shock
Strain Relief bend cycle test

Potential Failure Mode: Quick disconnect cable intermittent connection
Potential Failure Effects: No audio or intermittent audio over headset
Potential Causes: Line-to-Line contact design on commercially available connectors.  This minimum contact engagement is susceptible to  premature wear out and eventually results to non-contact.
Preventive Controls:
Avoid use of commercially available Quick Disconnect (QD) cables for Zebra applications.
Increase contact engagement on QD by 3mm.
Detection Controls:
Connect/Disconnect life cycle test
Teardown inspection of mating surfaces

Potential Failure Mode: Cable breaking at strain relief
Potential Causes: Cable Strain Relief design geometry induce stress concentration on cable bend.
Preventive Controls: Adopt proven Strain Relief design such as alternating cuts spaced in progression to avoid a concentrated bend point.
Detection Controls:
Thermal Shock test
Strain Relief bend cycle test over temperature range

Potential Failure Mode: Particle visible on display backlight
Potential Causes:
Lack of support structure on the back of display.
Double-sided adhesive on backlight frame is not wide enough and adhesive strength is not adequate.
Preventive Controls:
Design should provide support structure on the corners of the display to minimize movement of the backlight module during drops or tumble.
Backlight adhesive contact area and adhesive strength should be sufficient to allow the backlight module to withstand impact shock.
Detection Controls:
Thermal Shock
Drop test across temperature
Tumble test

Potential Failure Mode: Ripples on display when finger pressed
Potential Failure Effects: Appearance of localized distortion on display
Potential Causes: Interference points to the back of display module when pressure is applied on the display.
Preventive Controls:
Design should provide a uniform support structure on the back of display. 
Components placed underneath the display should have sufficient clearance to prevent interference when pressure is applied on the display during normal use.
Detection Controls: Add check item for ripples on display when pressure is applied during function testing.

Potential Failure Mode: Touch Panel glass shattering
Potential Causes: TP glass shattering due to cracks initiating from the edges due to chippings i.e., poor edge quality.
Preventive Controls:
Use alumino-silicate (Corning Gorilla Glass or equivalent) for applications with chemical strengthening.  Alumino-silicate glass can be post processed with Hydroflouric acid etch to improve edge quality.
Specifications for glass component should include the glass substrate material.
Detection Controls:
Four-point bend testing on glass components
First Article Inspection with microscope check on the glass edges for presence of chipping.
Thermal Shock
Drop Test across temperature
Tumble Test
Ball Drop on Touch Panel/ Display

Potential Failure Mode: Touch Panel damaged on the edge area
Potential Causes: Housing design did not adequately protect the edges of the touch panel
Preventive Controls:
Design should provide bottom edge protection to housing and keypad bezel and maintain the active area aligned within the  touch panel specification.
Touch panel design should include venting feature. Vent will allow for pressure equalization between touch panel and atmosphere.
Detection Controls:
Perform touch panel edge wear/ swipe testing.
Touch Panel durability life test.

Potential Failure Mode: IP leak failure on Touch Panel
Potential Failure Effects: IP seal compromised and could result to potential function loss
Potential Causes: Touch panel sensor surface does not cover the touch panel outline so it does not match with sealing adhesive area.
Preventive Controls: Touch panel design should ensure the outline is covered. Add fake sensor material if required to cover any exposed areas and use resin to fill any gaps.
Detection Controls:
Thermal Shock
IP Tests

Potential Failure Mode: ESD test failure at 12KV
Potential Failure Effects: Touch Panel partially operative or permanently damage
Potential Causes: Thickness of metal jumper between 8 - 16 microns could get damaged and bridge the glass-glass SITO touch panel configuration.
Preventive Controls: Design should ensure minimum thickness of 24 microns on glass-glass SITO (single-sided ITO) touch panel configuration.
Detection Controls: Thermal Shock + Operating Temperature Cycling + Vibration + ESD

Potential Failure Mode: Puffiness on Touch Panel
Potential Failure Effects: Puffiness increases the stress on the ITO layer and can lead to premature breakdown of the ITO resulting in non-linearity and dead zones.
Potential Causes:
Puffiness caused by the blocking of the vents in the touch panel design.
Vents can be blocked due to the flow of the adhesive that bonds the layers of the touch panel into the venting areas.
Preventive Controls:
Design to ensure the vents will not be blocked as a result of adhesive flow. 
The Display/Touch Panel gasket should be designed to provide relief in the areas of the vent to allow for unrestricted air flow.
Detection Controls:
Thermal Shock
Operating Temperature Cycling
Low Temperature Operating Function Test
High Temperature Operating Function Test

Potential Failure Mode: Distorted image when pressure is applied to Touch Panel
Potential Causes: Inadequate clearance between Touch Panel / Display shield can and mainboard shields causing pressure being applied on back of display resulting to localized distortion.
Preventive Controls:
1) Perform 1st order approximation (hand calculation) of Touch Panel / Display bending during user activation, approximately 100 grams.
2) Perform tolerance analysis to determine clearance between display shield and mainboard shield on the worst case stack-up. Clearance should be greater than the first order approximation.
3) Perform FEA of finalized Touch Panel + Display design to determine maximum applied force to cause interference between display shield can and mainboard shields.  There should be clearance with the shield can even in loaded condition.
Detection Controls:
Perform following test to establish presence or conditions necessary to create LCD distortion from Touch Panel use.  

First determine the location minimum clearance between the shield can of the Display and mainboard.  Apply compression at this location.
a) Test on Instron machine. Lay sample on a hard flat surface.
b) Have the plunger push down on the Touch Panel to a given force carefully observing the Display during the pull away for pressure marks.
c) If no pressure marks observed, increase pressure by 10g increments until distortion is observed.

Potential Failure Mode: Touch Panel is lifting up from plastic housing
Potential Failure Effects: Sealing compromised around Touch Panel could result to function loss.
Potential Causes:
Incorrect contact angle between the Touch Panel, Double-sided adhesive and Plastic housing.
Impurities on the bonding surface between Touch Panel and Plastic housing and bonding fixture parameters not optimized.
Preventive Controls:
Design should establish if the contact angle between mating surfaces is correct.  Dyne Pen test can be used for this purpose. Confirm there is no interference between the mating surfaces e.g. TP sensor film, FPC, etc.
Ensure cleanliness on the bonding surfaces.  Consider plasma cleaning if needed.
Ensure bonding parameters i.e., pressure and hold time are optimized.
Detection Controls:
Thermal Shock
Drop Test across temperature
Tumble Test

Potential Failure Mode: Touch Panel cracking during AFM test cycle
Potential Failure Effects: Possible premature Touch Panel failure in the field rendering the device inoperable
Potential Causes:
Lack of protective bezel or ledge on top housing to protect the Touch Panel / Display assembly.
Prioritization of ID preference over mechanical design intent.
Preventive Controls: Design should include protective features such as bezel depth on Top Housing to protect the Touch Panel / Display assembly.
Detection Controls:
mini-AFM test cycle
AFM test cycle
Drops across temperature
Tumble test

Potential Failure Mode: Screw boss cracking
Potential Failure Effects: Screw loosening leading to compromised sealing which could result to function loss
Potential Causes:
Cracks due to approved nyseal on screws in boss locations attacking plastics and and exacerbated by the non-optimal ultrasonic insertion process of brass inserts.

Screw nyseal attack on plastics due to unauthorized use of a equivalent version of nyseal by the supplier.
Preventive Controls:
Part drawing to specify only approved nyseal material is permitted to be used on the screws.
Perform mold flow analysis and avoid using nyseal on areas with high stress concentration.
Detection Controls:
Thermal Shock
Operating temperature cycling
Drops across temperature
Tumble test

Potential Failure Mode: Separation of BGA solder joint from solder pad
Potential Causes: Delamination of BGA from plated PCB finish.
Preventive Controls:
Ensure compatibility of BGA chemistry with Reflow temperature profile.
Ensure no mixed chemistry i.e. Pb free process with Pb BGA.
Ensure plated surface for BGA is Organic Solder Preservative (OSP) and not Electroless Nickel Gold (ENiG).
Verify selective plating of PCB for Ground Pad, surface contact board-to-board, antenna contact pad or PCB surface EMI contact shield/gasket is not OSP.
Use underfill or corner bond to provide strength against impact shock and PCB bending.
Detection Controls:
Drop test across temperature
Design margin testing
First Article Inspection to confirm PCB plating.  
Include PCB plating surface test report or C of C in FAI and Process Sign Off (PSO)

Potential Failure Mode: RF shielding not effective
Potential Causes: Incompatible surface finish for conductive contact or shielding.
Preventive Controls:
Ensure compatibility of contact elements (EMI gasket, Metal Ground, Board-to-Board contact).
Ensure no dis-similar metal to metal contact to avoid galvanic corrosion.
Verify plated surface for contact area for shielding is Electroless Nickel Gold (ENiG) and not Organic Solder Preservative (OSP).
Verify selective plating of PCB if Ground Pad, Surface board-to-board contact, Antennae contact pad or PCB EMI contact shield/gasket is not OSP.
Detection Controls:
Drop test across temperature
Design margin testing
First Article Inspection on PCB including check for plating
Include plating surface test report or C of C in FAI and evidence for PSO

Potential Failure Mode: Key press multiplied or different keys are displayed
Potential Causes:
PCB electrical interference for EL backlight driver.
The EL lines are long and routed above the Keypad matrix lines causing interference.
Preventive Controls:
